event_deployed_to.name: Albania - Earthquake
event_deployed_to.summary:
On 26 November 2019, a 6.4 magnitude earthquake hit Albania at 3.54 am local time, centred 30 km west of Tirana, at a depth of 10 km. A second earthquake of 5.4 magnitude followed at 7.10 am with the epicentre near Durres (34 km northwest of Tirana) and aftershocks (peaking above Magnitude 4) in subsequent weeks. 51 people lost their lives and 913 people were injured. The Government of Albania (GoA) declared a state of emergency on 27 November lasting for 30 days, later on extended until 31 March 2020.

11,490 housing units have been classified as fully destroyed / to be demolished, and another 83,745 housing units are classified as partially damaged, requiring repair (25 January 2020, damage assessments ongoing).

Figures on persons sheltering in hotels (1,991 individuals, funded by the GoA) and in tents (10,000 individuals) are precise, whilst there are no reliable figures available for people living in host families, people who are renting temporary accommodation or those who found other shelter solutions on their own. Tent camps and collective shelters (gyms, social centres) hosting displaced persons in initial weeks were closed. Informal estimations on the overall number of displaced persons, currently living in temporary accommodations, stand at 32,000. (25 January 2020)

The Albanian RC, supported by IFRC (8 Rapid Response Personnel in country at present) has been responding with a total of 350 volunteers and staff from the onset of the disaster. Immediate response included the provision of First Aid, food assistance (both with hot and cold food), psychosocial support services, distribution of household items to cover basic needs and Restoring Family Links (RFL). In subsequent weeks, focus was given to relief distributions (shelter and household items, food, and hygiene material) and PSS. Primary regions of activity are the prefectures of Durrës (Durrës city, Krujë, Shijak, Thumanë), Tiranë (Kamëz, Tiranë city, Vorë), Lezhë (Laç, Shëngjin). Winterisation of tents became a priority in late December and early January, with a large percentage of tent not suitable for winter conditions; subsequent focus was given to distributions of winterisation material in a joint effort of GoA and humanitarian agencies. As of 22 January 2020, ARC has been present in 85 different locations across the affected area. Ten branches have been actively involved in response operations.

Operational focus will shift to multipurpose cash grants and assistance through mutlifunctional mobile teams in the upcoming weeks.

event_deployed_to.name: Ebola Virus Disease Response and Containment
event_deployed_to.summary:
Situation

On 7 February 2021, the Minister of Health announcement of the resurgence of EVD in Biena health zone, Butembo territory. After the confirmation of the first case in the Masoya health area . According to the Ministry of Health, it concerns a farmer, wife of an Ebola survivor. She showed the typical signs of the disease on 1 February and went to the health centre in Biena where the sample was taken, before going on to the Matanda hospital in Butembo. She died on February 3 and the Gene Xpert result came back positive. On 10 February 2021, a second confirmed case of EVD was notified in the Biena health zone, Masoya health area. This is a 60-year-old farmer, who died on 10 February 2021, with an epidemiological link to the first case. This new outbreak has been declared in the backdrop of spread of the CoVid19 pandemic across the country.

Response

In response to this complex situation IFRC, has sent a Rapid Response Team to Biena so start supporting EVD response and it continues to support efforts to contain CoVid19 epidemic in North Kivu and Ituri as well as the recovery in Equateur province. The team in the field with focus on decontaminating the houses of confirmed patients and performing Safe and Dignified Burials. 

Constraints
Access constrains to the affected area and community resistance are key challenges for the response, IFRC and DRC RC are implementing the lessons from the previous outbreaks to reach these areas and work with communities to reduce resistance.

event_deployed_to.name: Sudan : Floods (2020)
event_deployed_to.summary:
Heavy rains in Sudan started on 28 July and intensified during August and September. The rain has caused flooding, destruction of infrastructure, houses, both private and public, and have displaced thousands of people in multiple locations across the country. The torrential rain has taken almost 140 lives

The flooding has affected all 18 states of Sudan. The most affected states are Khartoum, Blue Nile, Sennar, North Darfur and West Darfur, which account for 52 per cent of all people affected.

 

Access to many affected areas are still limited, and the assessments are ongoing. The data will be updated continuously. As the assessments progress the number of affected people continues to rise. By 1 October the number of affected people had risen to over 860 000 according to HAC. About half of the affected population are children. Other vulnerable groups affected are old people, approximately 40 000, and disabled people, approximately 125 000. The full impact of the floods will reveal itself when the water has receded, and all areas are accessible for assessments.

 

The health situation is deteriorating due to stagnant, contaminated water. Malaria, diarrhoea and skin infection are common causes of mortality among children and malaria is a common cause of illness among adults. In the northern part of the country there are over 100 cases of unknow fever diseases recorded. In many of the flooded places here is no, or very limited, access to clean water. The water supply from boreholes have been affected by overflow of the river and latrines are overflooded. The risk of water contamination and outbreak of waterborne diseases is growing.

 

With water sources being infected, houses damaged and destroyed, the most pressing needs on the ground are wash and shelter. People need immediate access to clean drinking water. There is an urgent need to restore safe water sources, as well as latrines. People having lost their homes urgently need houses repaired or rebuilt.

 

Soaring inflation hits the most vulnerable, increases humanitarian needs, and is a real challenge to aid agencies. Prices increase on a weekly basis, in some cases prices have doubled since June-July. Inflation reached nearly 170 per cent in August, according to the Central Bureau of Statistics of Sudan. The average price of the local food basket increased by nearly 200 per cent compared to 2019, according to the World Food Program.

 

The inflation contributes to the food insecurity, already experienced due to flooded crops. Food insecurity was expected to reach level 2 and is currently at level 3. The last few months 9.6 million people in Sudan are facing food insecurity of level 3, or higher. Another 15.9 million people are facing level 2.

 

The first case of COVID-19 was recorded in Sudan 12 March 2020. Though the number of infected people remain relatively low, the virus is present, and the necessary precautions must be taken. To date there are over 13 600 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Sudan, and the number of deaths recorded is 836. These are the registered cases, but because of a lack of efficient registrations the real numbers are believed to be higher.

 

The situation is expected to further deteriorate over the coming months. The rainy season is not over, and more rainfall is expected according to the Sudanese Meteorological Authority. The continuing inflation will increase the number of people who need assistance and hampering humanitarian’s capacity to respond. The gradual reduction of fuel subsidies planned by the Government is likely to push inflation further up and negatively impact vulnerable families, as well as increase costs of humanitarian assistance.

The first case of COVID-19 was recorded in Sudan 12 March 2020. Though the number of infected people remain relatively low, the virus is present, and the necessary precautions must be taken. To date there are over 13 600 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Sudan, and the number of deaths recorded is 836. These are the registered cases, but because of a lack of efficient registrations the real numbers are believed to be higher.

 

The situation is expected to further deteriorate over the coming months. The rainy season is not over, and more rainfall is expected according to the Sudanese Meteorological Authority. The continuing inflation will increase the number of people who need assistance and hampering humanitarian’s capacity to respond. The gradual reduction of fuel subsidies planned by the Government is likely to push inflation further up and negatively impact vulnerable families, as well as increase costs of humanitarian assistance.

event_deployed_to.summary:

The rain has caused flooding, destruction of infrastructure, houses, both private and public, and have displaced thousands of people in multiple locations across the country. The torrential rain has taken almost 140 lives

The flooding has affected all 18 states of Sudan. The most affected states are Khartoum, Blue Nile, Sennar, North Darfur and West Darfur, which account for 52 per cent of all people affected.

 

Access to many affected areas are still limited, and the assessments are ongoing. The data will be updated continuously. As the assessments progress the number of affected people continues to rise. By 1 October the number of affected people had risen to over 860 000 according to HAC. About half of the affected population are children. Other vulnerable groups affected are old people, approximately 40 000, and disabled people, approximately 125 000. The full impact of the floods will reveal itself when the water has receded, and all areas are accessible for assessments.

Malaria, diarrhoea and skin infection are common causes of mortality among children and malaria is a common cause of illness among adults. There is an urgent need to restore safe water sources, as well as latrines. People having lost their homes urgently need houses repaired or rebuilt.

event_deployed_to.name: Philippines - Typhoon GONI
event_deployed_to.summary:
The impact of Typhoon Goni in in the northern central Philippines has been substantial, with devastating impact in certain localities particularly Bicol Region V – Catanduanes and Albay particularly appear to be hard hit. On the evening of 27 October 2020, a tropical depression developed over the Western Pacific Ocean, Northwest of Guam. Once inside the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) it has been given local name “Rolly” (Goni). As per the state-run Philippines Atmospheric Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA), Typhoon Goni made its landfall in Bato, Catanduanes, at 04:50 am local time on 1 November 2020.

Typhoon Goni made landfall as a super typhoon with maximum sustained winds of 225 kilometers per hour and gustiness of up to 280 kilometers per hour and moved west southwest at 25 kilometers per hour, making the second landfall over Tiwi, Albay at 07:20 am and the third landfall over San Narciso, Quezon at 12:00 pm.

At the time of landfall, PAGASA raised Tropical Cyclone Wind Signals as per the Bulletin #13. For Signal 5, it can be expected that there will be widespread damage to high-risk structures. Very heavy damage to medium-risk structures. Almost total damage to structures of light materials, especially in highly exposed coastal areas. Complete roof failure on many residences and industrial buildings. Electrical power distribution and communication services severely disrupted. Total damage to banana plantation. Most tall trees are broken, uprooted or defoliated. Coconut trees are stooped, broken or uprooted. Few plants and trees survived.
